comments.commentBody: It's amazing how easy it is to bait this "President". Keep the bait coming Democrats. If Trump is kept busy tweeting responses to all of the attacks on his administration he won't be able to destroy this country with executive orders,or in Trumpspeak, making "America great again".

It's not the politics, it's the money!

Until we know the full extent of the financial exposure that Trump and the Trump Organization have to Russia, we will never know the real story of the Trump-Putin connection. Trump ran the Miss Universe pageant in Moscow for a considerable profit. New York real estate is a notorious money-laundering ground for the Russian oil oligarchs.

Given all this and the fact that no Russian international business is carried on without Putin's consent (not to mention his frequently taking something off the top of the transaction), it is inconceivable that there are no Trump-Russia financial ties, ties that may be putting our national security interests at risk.

Just follow the money...

More than any of these accounts, which are disturbing by themselves, the thing which astounds me is the GOP's closing ranks against an independent investigation.  Really, if there is nothing there then let's prove that.  Also, the tax returns would go a long way to establishing credibility for the president in this matter.

I guess the people who supported Trump should thank Hillary for being the feckless candidate she was.  Looks like the "deplorables" got to have the last word.  And the shouting, the mindless shouting.  Couldn't she have just spoken in a normal voice and turned up the volume.  She just oozed insincerity and ambition.  The people saw it, the ones who don't get their news from a paper of record every day, and decided to go with the clown, who at least seemed to say what he was thinking.

Trump is an ugly man -- a groper, a fraudster, a narcissist, an sycophant to a much crueler and more practiced tyrant ... and seemingly in early dementia now too.

It's a waste of time to expect anything more or better from Mr. Trump.

@Lee HARRISON: I don't know what your level of formal education is, but it appears that the only criterium to be published is to be anti Trump.Ms. Sullivan stressed that comments must be informative, but your remarks reflect only your own prejudices, and do not otherwise enlighten us. Hard for comments of substance from those with a different viewpoint to get a hearing,which leaves me with the conclusion that the Comments section is rigged against us who support the President unconditionally, and we do not appreciate being put down  as misogynist, xenophobic, Islamophobic--one of my wives is Muslim from Senegal--by those, mainly white, who live in genteel neighborhoods, far from the perilous housing projects where we r forced to reside.How can you say such things about someone whom you have never met, much less interviewed?TRUMP gave a "bonne gifle"to all those self righteous folks who have ignored us "petits blancs" for decades.He is attempting to restore American pride, make this country liveable for all Americans, and you should be aware of that."Cynicism is cheap' you can find it on any street corner" wrote Graham GREENE generations ago.Friend of mine who is anti Trump nonetheless is grateful for the rise in value of her 401K thanks in part to the c-in-c.
he hasn't built the wall. he hasn't brought back jobs. he hasn't punished the north koreans for firing off a missile. and all those congressional members? republicans.
I just never thought that by "domestic" threats, we would have to deal with one in the White House. This is surreal.

Americans seem to have a singular inability to view themselves in the harsh light of reality. Blame the myth of "exceptionalism" but you have to ask yourself if something is seriously wrong when your country jails more of its citizens than any country in history. You have to ask yourself what's wrong when you spend more on health care than any other nation but your citizens have worse health outcomes. Why is there so much poverty in the world's richest nation? Why is our electoral system an arcane 18th century artifact? Why do we spend more on the military than the next 15 nations combined? Why are our children falling behind the Chinese, Koreans, Japanese, Finns, Germans, Swedes. . . . . . . .

Why do polititians get elected who have no solution to these problems but rather propose policies that will only make them worse? I nearly fell on the floor when I recently heard Daryll Issa say that the U.S. should look to Canada and Europe for ways to improve Obamacare. Have the scales fallen from his eyes?
I don't know exactly what you're suggesting by "better." People ultimately must own the decisions they make, and yes, some decisions are better than others.

Perhaps Julia Joffe's closing sentence will jar America's hubristic sense of exceptionalism, now bound to destroy the fabric of its (fading) greatness :
"“This is probably what it felt like to be a British foreign service officer after World War II, when you realize, no, the sun actually does set on your empire,” said the mid-level officer. “America is over. And being part of that, when it’s happening for no reason, is traumatic.”

Yup, despite having lost by 3 mio votes in the general, Don Trumplestielzchen has won bigly. Doesn't look like anyone asks about the 9 Yemeni children killed in his raid. Exxon as well as Rosnjeft are gonna give him a lot of money when he gets rid of the Russia sanctions (so he can finally be a net-millionaire), his brand name has quadrupled, his buddies won't have to pay so much taxes anymore (he never did, anyway) and all the Muslim countries (Saudi Arabia, UAE, Turkey) where he's got some business going on can travel to the US, terrorism or not - no problem. And I am sure the repatriation of tax shelter money for nothing from big companies will drive the stock prizes higher. I just wonder why you think you'll benefit.
Joe S, no one is trying to reason with Trump. He is not all-powerful. He can be contained. Doing nothing for 2 or 4 years is not an option.
We are past Clinton versus Trump.  Reality is that Potus 45 is a menace to America and the rest of the world.  Some can see it, some can't.
What shocks me is that the power of the Presidency goes so deep into the bureaucracy. Disarray within 6 weeks.

Look at Yemen, where the US used extremists to bring down a government and then left a country in anarchy. Look at Syria where the US fueled a civil war that killed half a million people. Look at Saudi Arabia and Israel where the US encourages local governments to have megalomaniac dreams that they can only hope to realize by staying dependent on the US. Look at Yemen, one of the victims of this policy. And these are just a few examples.

That is Fried's State Department. It is both morally broke and increasingly at odds with the diminishing role of the US in the world. Yet its behavior has only grown more extreme over the last two decades.

Sometimes you need an ignorant outsider to tell you that the emperor doesn't wear any clothes.

Sorry Roger but the State Department under Clinton was a swamp that needed to be drained: I realize there is a blackout on certain news in The Times and therefore will ignore the uniformed Hillary chorus in the comment section but really the swath of misery left by this crew at State under Hill the Shill in Honduras, Haiti, Syria, Libya and Ukraine is massive even by the  high bar we set and there not an island too far that Nuland and Ambassador Pyatt  should be posted too, this  toxic little duo nearly brought the world down around our ears; but of course I don't expect any support from the Times or its readers on this, as the information seeping past the sensors is just now beginning to surface, talk about fake news, how about just no news, evasion or outright lies on the above issues. The regime changes ending in misery for the people  under Clinton equal anything done under Reagan, good riddance to Clinton, Nuland, Pyatt, Fried and the whole sordid bunch.

So, Simon. Your real fear is -- do we have this right? -- is that those illegal migrants who will labor in our fields and struggle to become citizens of this sorta wonderful nation will all vote as Democrats?

Is that why they're "tapeworms?" (And what does that make the rest of us Dems? Weevils?)

Notwithstanding State's four-month tours in Iraq, it is No wonder the Foreign Circus is loathed by the members of the Armed Forces at the end of the whip of the state department's many failures.

Fire them all and let God sort em' out!

Yet it was Bismarck who brought Germans universal health insurance in 1873. A feat no American president has managed to do.

By the way, the English term 'folk' is directly derived from 'Volk' meaning essentially the same, 'people'. Any American who refers to 'The People' effectively says 'Das Volk'.

It's not a bad a word, it's only what liberals make out of it.

Yes, Daniel Fried's words should be in front of the President ... but also in front of every single one of us to see, remember, and consider every day (they are on my office bulletin board right now). Thanks, Roger Cohen, for this thoughtful and clear piece and for also bringing the perspective of Daniel Fried to Times readers (and, one can only hope, many more). Mr. Fried, please write articles and books; I, for one, would like to hear more from you.

"There is a long list of contempts regarding this president, the least of which is a contempt and disregard for the Constitution."  If you really think that contempt for the Constitution is the least of it, you think it a small thing and join Trump in his contempt for it.

Do not lose track of the ultimate objective.
Demand those tax returns NOW.
Resist. Organize.
Dump the Trump
and all his chumps.
The author of this post should cite his stats.  The 90% of journalists remark is particularly absurd.  False facts, again.  Sad.
No.  Contempt for the Constitution is not the least.  It underlies all the rest.

When Mr. Cohen refers to President's oath to "preserve, protect an defend the Constitution of the United States" and goes on to say that the oath is to the law and not the "volk", he makes a critical distinction. Volk is German for "people" and is a concept employed by Hitler and his regime  to create a nationalistic spirit in order to justify the horrors imposed upon Germany and the world. Making America great again may sound good when said quickly, but we must stop and ask ourselves - at what price.
